title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: We started from Newhaven by a small steamboat,passing, on our way up the Firth, Queensferry, Culross, and Alloa.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Culross was also celebrated for its salt-pans and coal mines.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: T Culross was famous for the manufacture of girdles, the round iron plates on which the people of Scotland bake their barley and oaten bread.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: At the Reformation, its possessions were conferred upon Sir James Colville, who was created Lord Colville of Culross.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On the north side is Valleyfield (Lady Bau-d Preston), and near it the ancient and decayed burgh of Culross (pronounced Cooross).f The inhabitants are a remarkably primitive set of people.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: — Perth, Culross, Crieff, Callander, Kincardine,  Doune, Comrie, Dunblane, Auchterarder, Dunkeld, and Blairgowrie.

title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: All night, then, we walked through the north side of the Carse under the high line of the Ochil mountains ; and by Alloa and Clackmannan and Culross, all of which we avoided ; and about ten in the morning, mighty hungry and tired, came to the little clachan of Limekilns.

title: The works of the Right Rev. John Sage,
author: Sage, John
snippet: Knox says there werepresent in the Parhament holden in August 1560, whichParliament gave the first national establishment to ourReformation, the Bishop of GaUoway, the Abbots of Lindores, Culross, St Colm's Inch, Coldingham, St Mary-Isle,and the Sub-Prior of St Andrews, with diverse others;and of all these he says that " they had renouncedPapistry, and openly professed Jesus Christ."! Spottiswoode reckons up no fewer than eight of the Spiritual Estate,all Protestants, chosen at that time to be Lords of the Articles, namely, the Bishops of GaUoway and Argyll, the Priorof St Andrews, the Abbots of Aberbrothwick, Kilwinning,Lindores, Newbottle, and Culross.2 Lay these two accountstogether, and you shall have at least a round dozen of Reforming Prelates.

Spottiswoode reckons up no fewer than eight of the Spiritual Estate,all Protestants, chosen at that time to be Lords of the Articles, namely, the Bishops of GaUoway and Argyll, the Priorof St Andrews, the Abbots of Aberbrothwick, Kilwinning,Lindores, Newbottle, and Culross.2 Lay these two accountstogether, and you shall have at least a round dozen of Reforming Prelates.
